questions.text:
A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of 2-day history of confusion and anuria. He has chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia at the age of 8 years and was treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplantation. He is HIV-positive and has an active hepatitis C virus infection. He drinks around eight cans of beer every week. His current medications include tenofovir, emtricitabine, atazanavir, daclatasvir, sofosbuvir, insulin, amlodipine, and enalapril. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Examination shows severe edema in both legs and generalized muscular weakness. Auscultation of the lungs show crepitant rales. Laboratory studies show positive HCV antibody and positive HCV RNA. His HIV viral load is undetectable and his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 589/mm3. Six months ago, his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count was 618/mm3. An ECG of the heart shows arrhythmia with frequent premature ventricular contractions. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.23


PCO2

31 mm Hg


HCO3-

13 mEq/L


Base excess
-12 mEq/L


The patient states he would like to donate organs or tissues in the case of his death. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for organ donation in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis C infection is not an absolute contraindication for organ donation. Donor organs from hepatitis C-positive donors may be offered to hepatitis C-positive recipients, even if the virus can be detected in the blood, as in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

HIV infection was formerly an absolute contraindication for organ donation and legally prohibited individuals from becoming organ donors in the US. This rule was based on the principle of nonmaleficence, as transplantation of HIV-positive donor organs may pose harm to transplant recipients. However, the HIV Organ Policy Equity (HOPE) Act implemented in November 2015 now allows transplantation of organs from HIV-positive donors to HIV-positive recipients, provided the donor has an undetectable viral load, no prior history of an opportunistic infection, no active fungal infection, and a CD4+ count over 500 cells/μL for a 6-month period prior to donation. None of these restrictions apply to this patient. This patient's history of HIV does not, therefore, affect his eligibility to donate his organs to HIV-positive recipients. Donor organs from HIV-positive individuals are not transplanted to non-HIV-positive patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Although incurable or metastatic malignancy is an absolute contraindication for organ donation, this patient's history of childhood leukemia with a long cancer-free interval does not prohibit organ donation. Organ donation from individuals with low-grade, localized tumors without evidence of metastasis is also permitted.

D) INCORRECT:

Alcoholism is a contraindication for pancreas donation, but not for solid organ donations in general. Another contraindication for pancreas donation is diabetes mellitus. Alcohol use disorder (as well as substance use disorder) is also a contraindication for undergoing liver transplantation.

E) CORRECT:

Absolute contraindications for organ donation include incurable or metastatic malignancy, sepsis, transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (e.g., Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease), and cardiac arrest that occurred before brain death, none of which apply to this patient. HIV infection was previously an absolute contraindication for organ donation and legally prohibited individuals from becoming organ donors in the US, but the 2015 HIV Organ Policy Equity (HOPE) act allows transplantation of organs from HIV-positive donors to HIV-positive recipients at certain institutions.
questions.hint: This patient's medical history has to be thoroughly reviewed for any incurable illnesses or malignancies.

questions.text: Ten days after undergoing a cadaveric renal transplant, a 21-year-old man has pain in the right lower abdomen and generalized fatigue. During the past 2 days, he has had decreasing urinary output. He passed 5 liters of urine on the second postoperative day and serum studies showed a creatinine concentration of 2.1 mg/dL. He has adult polycystic kidney disease and was on maintenance hemodialysis for 2 months prior to transplantation. Current medications include azathioprine, cyclosporine, prednisone, and enalapril. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 101/min, and blood pressure is 164/94 mm Hg. Examination shows a healing surgical incision in the right lower abdomen. The graft site shows tenderness to palpation. His blood urea nitrogen concentration is 52 mg/dL, creatinine concentration is 4.1 mg/dL. A biopsy of the transplanted kidney shows tubulitis. C4d staining is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Abdominal pain, hypertension, generalized fatigue, and an increase in creatinine within 6 months of renal transplantation are concerning for acute rejection of the renal allograft. The two mechanisms for acute allograft rejection are acute cellular rejection by host T-lymphocytes and acute humoral rejection by circulating antibodies. The absence of C4d staining (a marker of antibody-mediated damage) and the presence of inflammatory infiltrate within the wall of tubules (tubulitis) indicate that the most likely mechanism for graft rejection in this patient is acute cellular rejection.

B) INCORRECT:

Calcineurin inhibitors such as cyclosporine cause reversible renal vasoconstriction, which would result in increased serum creatinine (due to a decrease in GFR caused by afferent arteriole constriction) and hypertension (due to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system). However, the BUN:creatinine ratio would usually be > 20:1 in conditions associated with renal hypoperfusion. Also, the renal biopsy would show vacuoles within the tubular cells rather than cellular infiltrate within the tubular epithelium (tubulitis).

Acute calcineurin nephrotoxicity can sometimes manifest as thrombotic microangiopathy, which can result in a mild inflammatory infiltrate. However, the renal biopsy would also show thrombi within the glomerular vessels in the case of thrombotic microangiopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Preformed antibodies against class I HLA of the graft are responsible for hyperacute rejection of the renal allograft, which would result in features of acute renal failure (e.g., decreased urine output, increased creatinine) as well as tubulitis on renal biopsy. However, patients with preformed antibodies would usually have a history of blood transfusion in the past or a failed organ transplantation, and the onset of acute renal failure in a case of hyperacute renal graft rejection would always occur within 48 hours of transplantation. The renal biopsy would also have shown widespread infarction, necrosis, and thrombosis as well as C4d along the glomerular and peritubular capillaries.

D) INCORRECT:

Damage to the recipient's tissue by donor T-cells (graft-versus-host disease) can occur following allogenous stem cell transplantation; it is not typically seen with solid organ transplantation because most solid organ grafts (e.g., kidney, heart) do not contain much lymphoid tissue. Moreover, graft-versus-host disease typically manifests with gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea), hepatic dysfunction, and skin lesions, not acute renal failure.

E) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the ureterovesical anastomosis by a hematocele or lymphocele can cause features of acute renal failure (increased creatinine, oliguria/anuria) and abdominal discomfort within the first few weeks of renal transplant surgery. However, evidence of tubulitis on renal biopsy suggests a different cause for renal failure.

F) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of the tunica intima of glomerular vessels is a pathological finding seen in chronic renal allograft rejection, which can result in renal failure and hypertension. However, chronic rejection of the renal allograft typically manifests > 6 months after the transplantation with gradually increasing creatinine and proteinuria, unlike this patient who developed acute renal failure one week after the transplantation.

G) INCORRECT:

Reactivation of a BK polyomavirus infection by immunosuppressant therapy can cause polyomavirus-associated nephropathy, which would manifest with renal dysfunction as well as tubulitis on a renal biopsy. However, the renal dysfunction would be slowly progressive, and it usually occurs 3–4 months after transplantation. Also, the biopsy would show intranuclear inclusion bodies.

H) INCORRECT:

Denovo synthesis of antibodies by B-cells against HLA antigens can result in acute humoral rejection of the renal allograft, which would manifest with abdominal pain, hypertension, generalized fatigue, and an increase in creatinine within 6 months of renal transplantation. However, an inflammatory infiltrate in the glomerular endothelium as well as C4d staining of the glomerular and peritubular capillaries would be present on renal biopsy.
questions.hint: After renal transplant from a cadaveric donor, the serum creatinine should start to decrease by the end of the first week. This patient will therefore most likely require pulse corticosteroid therapy.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of low-grade fever and generalized fatigue. During this period, she has passed decreased amounts of urine. Two months ago, she underwent a renal allograft transplant because of reflux nephropathy. There is no family history of serious illness. Her current medications include prednisone, cyclosporine, and azathioprine. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 160/94 mm Hg. Examination shows several white patches within the oral cavity. There is a well-healed surgical incision over the right lower abdomen. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
6000/mm3



Platelet count
156,000/mm3



Serum



 Urea nitrogen
89 mg/dL


 Glucose
76 mg/dL


 Creatinine
3.9 mg/dL


 Donor-specific antibodies
negative


A biopsy of the allograft shows mononuclear infiltrates with tubulitis and arteritis. C4d staining is negative. Oral fluconazole is administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin therapy has been proven effective in the treatment of patients with acute humoral (i.e., B-cell mediated) rejection. Acute humoral rejection is a rare type of acute rejection that usually manifests with positive C4d staining on biopsy, indicating antibody deposition.

B) CORRECT:

The best initial step in the treatment of patients with biopsy-confirmed acute renal allograft rejection (which is most commonly a cellular rejection) is pulse steroid therapy (e.g., a short course of high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone). While pulse steroid therapy induces reversal in two-thirds of cases, the use of anti-T-cell antibodies or a dose increase/switch in immunosuppressants may be indicated for refractory rejection. Acute transplant rejection is the only type of graft rejection that can be reversed.

High-dose steroids may aggravate immunosuppression in transplant patients, thereby increasing the risk of opportunistic infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Removal of the graft is indicated in hyperacute rejection, which is rare, and chronic rejection. The timing of this patient's rejection reaction, however, does not fit with either of these types. While hyperacute and chronic rejections are irreversible, this patient's acute rejection can be reversed with appropriate treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Plasmapheresis is indicated in the treatment of acute humoral (i.e., B-cell mediated) rejection. Most acute rejections are due to a cellular (T-cell mediated) rather than a humoral response. In addition, this patient's negative C4d staining on biopsy indicates the absence of antibody deposition (part of the humoral immune response).

E) INCORRECT:

Radiation of the graft should only be used as rescue therapy in patients with acute rejection after multiple unsuccessful treatment attempts, as there is little evidence regarding the safety and efficacy of this procedure. Other treatment options should first be exhausted before local graft irradiation is considered in this patient.
questions.hint: The presence of fever and decreased urinary output in combination with elevated blood urea and creatinine levels in a post-renal transplant individual 2 months after the procedure indicates an acute allograft rejection. The biopsy confirms an acute cellular rejection (the absence of C4d staining indicates no antibody deposition).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of malaise and abdominal pain. Six weeks ago, he had vomiting and watery diarrhea for 2 days that resolved without treatment. Twelve weeks ago, he underwent orthotopic liver transplantation for alcoholic cirrhosis. At the time of discharge, his total serum bilirubin concentration was 1.0 mg/dL. He stopped drinking alcohol one year ago. His current medications include daily tacrolimus, prednisone, valganciclovir, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. The abdomen is soft and tender to deep palpation over the right upper quadrant, where there is a well-healed surgical scar. His leukocyte count is 2500/mm3, serum bilirubin concentration is 2.6 mg/dL, and serum tacrolimus concentration is within therapeutic range. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) would be appropriate if the first-line diagnostic study suggested complications affecting the biliary tree. MRCP is not the first diagnostic modality in the workup of suspected acute liver transplant rejection, as it visualizes the biliary tract only and is furthermore time-consuming and expensive.

B) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is not the first-line radiologic study in the workup of suspected acute liver transplant rejection. Only if the first-line diagnostic modality suggests vascular complications (e.g., hepatic artery thrombosis), biliary complications (e.g., leak, stricture), or liver infection (e.g., perihepatic abscess), a CT scan would be appropriate. However, a more cost-effective method without radiation and contrast exposure should be conducted first.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral infection (e.g., HSV, CMV, EBV, hepatitis B or C viruses) can manifest with jaundice, abdominal pain, and elevated bilirubin. This patient is taking CMV prophylaxis (valganciclovir), making a herpes virus infection less likely. The rather unspecific clinical presentation of this patient (pain in the graft region, jaundice, and rising bilirubin) without associated fever raises concern for acute transplant rejection or other complications of liver transplantation (e.g., portal vein thrombosis, biliary leak, liver infection), which should be evaluated with a different diagnostic tool first. If infection remains the suspected cause of symptoms, testing for viral loads (viral particles detected by PCR) is appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Liver biopsy is the gold standard for the definitive diagnosis of acute transplant rejection and will likely be required in this patient at a later time. However, a biopsy is an invasive procedure associated with a small but considerable risk of complications, especially in liver transplant recipients. It can demonstrate pathologies of the liver parenchyma, but not of the extrahepatic vessels and biliary ducts. Since this patient's clinical findings are rather nonspecific, another less invasive diagnostic tool should be used first to rule out other potential post-transplant complications. In patients who are > 6 months post-transplantation, clinicians often proceed directly to liver biopsy in the setting of suspected hepatic dysfunction due to liver rejection.

E) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography provides excellent visualization of the biliary tree and would be appropriate in this patient (i.e., < 6 months post-transplant with hepatic dysfunction) after the first-line diagnostic tool suggested biliary pathology (e.g., dilation, stricture, leak). Since this patient's presentation is rather nonspecific and can be caused by other complications of liver transplantation (acute transplant rejection, vascular complications, infection), a more cost-effective and less invasive diagnostic modality should be performed first.

F) INCORRECT:

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy is usually performed if, e.g., gastritis, gastrointestinal bleeding, or formation (and/or possible bleeding) of esophageal varices is suspected. The rather unspecific clinical presentation of this patient (pain in the graft region, jaundice, and rising bilirubin) within 6 months after liver transplantation raises concern for acute transplant rejection or other complications of liver transplantation (e.g., portal vein thrombosis, biliary leak, liver infection), which should be evaluated with a different diagnostic tool.

G) CORRECT:

Since clinical findings for acute liver transplant rejection are nonspecific, duplex ultrasound of the liver should be performed to rule out possible vascular complications (e.g. portal vein thrombosis, bleeding), biliary complications (e.g., leak, stricture), and liver infection (e.g. perihepatic abscess). Duplex ultrasound is a noninvasive, precise, and cost-effective method that can be used at the patient's bedside. If acute transplant rejection is suspected, a liver biopsy showing interstitial lymphocytic infiltrate would confirm the diagnosis.
questions.hint: Acute liver transplant rejection can occur within 6 months after transplantation and may manifest with vomiting, jaundice, rising bilirubin, and pain in the graft region.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of excessive hair growth on her chin over the past 2 weeks. She also reports progressive enlargement of her gums. Three months ago, she underwent liver transplantation due to Wilson disease. Following the procedure, the patient was started on transplant rejection prophylaxis. She has a history of poorly-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dark-pigmented, coarse hair on the chin, upper lip, and chest. The gingiva and the labial mucosa are swollen. There is a well-healed scar on her right lower abdomen. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azathioprine is a drug used for liver transplantation rejection prophylaxis. Its most common side effects include pancytopenia due to myelosuppression, pancreatitis, diarrhea, and hepatotoxicity, none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, gingival hyperplasia and hirsutism are not typical side effects of this drug.

B) INCORRECT:

Daclizumab is no longer used for the prevention of liver transplant rejection. In addition, this patient has none of this drug's most common side effects, such as skin rash, lymphadenopathy, and elevated liver enzymes, but presents instead with gingival hyperplasia and hirsutism, which are not typical for daclizumab.

C) CORRECT:

Cyclosporine is a drug typically used for transplantation rejection prophylaxis. Side effects include hypertension, gingival hyperplasia, and hirsutism, making this the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms. Other common side effects of cyclosporine include nephrotoxicity, hyperlipidemia, hyperglycemia, tremor, and an increased risk of malignancies (esp. cutaneous squamous cell carcinomas) and infectious diseases (esp. upper respiratory and urinary tract infections).

See “Overview of immunosuppressants” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Although sirolimus is sometimes used for liver transplant prophylaxis, its side effects include hyperlipidemia, anemia, thrombocytopenia, arthralgia, and acne. Gingival hyperplasia and hirsutism are not characteristic side effects of sirolimus.

E) INCORRECT:

Tacrolimus is a drug indicated for transplantation rejection prophylaxis. Its most common side effects include hypertension, which this patient has, as well as hyperglycemia and nephrotoxicity, which are not reported here. Moreover, gingival hyperplasia and hirsutism are not typical side effects of this drug.

F) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is indicated for severe psoriasis, rheumatoid arthritis, and neoplastic diseases rather than for transplant rejection prophylaxis. Moreover, its side effects do not include gingival hyperplasia or hirsutism.

G) INCORRECT:

Mycophenolate mofetil is a cytostatic immunosuppressant drug that is used for transplantation rejection prophylaxis. Its most common side effects include bone marrow suppression, vomiting, diarrhea, peripheral edema, elevated blood urea nitrogen, and hyperglycemia, none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, gingival hyperplasia and hirsutism are not typical side effects of this medication.
questions.hint: This patient presents with gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism, and hypertension. Since the symptoms have started soon after her liver transplantation, an association with newly added medications appears likely. The drug that is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms is also used to treat rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. One month ago, he underwent a right-sided kidney transplantation due to severe polycystic kidney disease. Following the procedure, he was started on transplant rejection prophylaxis. He has had 5–6 bowel movements per day of loose stool and occasional vomiting. He appears pale. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10 g/dL


Leukocyte count
2500/mm3


Platelet count
80,000/mm3


Serum



 Glucose

210 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tacrolimus is commonly used as part of transplant rejection prophylaxis regimens. While its diabetogenic effects can cause hyperglycemia, pancytopenia is not a common adverse effect of tacrolimus.

B) INCORRECT:

Although methotrexate (MTX) use may cause pancytopenia, hyperglycemia is not a common adverse effect of MTX. In addition, MTX is used for the treatment of neoplastic and rheumatic diseases and is not typically indicated for transplant rejection prophylaxis.

C) CORRECT:

Mycophenolate mofetil is a cytostatic immunosuppressant drug used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. Some of the most common adverse effects associated with this drug include pancytopenia and hyperglycemia.

Gastrointestinal upset is a common adverse effect of almost all immunosuppressants. See “Overview of immunosuppressants” table.

D) INCORRECT:

Cyclosporine is commonly used as part of transplant rejection prophylaxis regimens. While its diabetogenic effects can cause hyperglycemia, pancytopenia is not a common adverse effect of cyclosporine.

E) INCORRECT:

Although basiliximab can be used as part of renal transplant rejection prophylaxis regimens, hyperglycemia and pancytopenia are not common adverse effects of basiliximab.
questions.hint: This patient's hypertension, hyperglycemia, and pancytopenia are most likely adverse effects of a medication used in transplant rejection prophylaxis regimens. Patients receiving this medication are at increased risk for severe bacterial and viral infections (especially cytomegalovirus infection).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of worsening fatigue, loss of appetite, itching of the skin, and progressive leg swelling. Although she has been drinking 2–3 L of water daily, she has been passing only small amounts of urine. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and diabetic polyneuropathy. Her current medications include insulin, torsemide, lisinopril, and synthetic erythropoietin. She appears pale. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 138/89 mm Hg. There is 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is decreased over the feet and legs bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
6000/mm3



Platelet count
280,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

137 mEq/L


 K+

5.3 mEq/L


 Cl−

100 mEq/L


 HCO3−

20 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
85 mg/dL


 Creatinine

8 mg/dL


 pH
7.25


Which of the following long-term treatments would best improve quality of life and maximize survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with acidosis, electrolyte abnormalities (hyperkalemia), ingestion of toxins (increased BUN), fluid overload (edema), and uremic symptoms (itching of the skin), all of which are indications for hemofiltration. Although renal replacement therapy is indicated in this patient and is necessary to bridge the time to definitive treatment, hemofiltration should not be continued as a long-term treatment, as it is associated with a variety of potential complications (e.g., thrombosis, infection, heart failure) that may impact survival. Moreover, it must be administered at least 3 times per week, which significantly reduces quality of life. Treatment associated with a better survival rate and quality of life should be pursued if available.

B) INCORRECT:

Kidney transplantation is indicated for patients with ESRD. The most frequently used surgical technique is heterotopic implantation in the iliac fossa, connecting the donor ureter to the recipient bladder. Although on average cadaveric kidney transplants function for approx. 14 years, it would not be the best long-term treatment option for this 45-year-old patient, because it is not associated with the greatest survival benefit.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms of fluid overload (e.g., peripheral edema). Although fluid intake should be restricted to approximately 2 L/day in order to prevent edema in this patient, it would not be the best long-term treatment option for a patient with ESRD.

D) CORRECT:

Kidney transplantation is indicated for patients with ESRD. In these cases, it is associated with a greater long-term survival rate and a better quality of life than dialysis. The most frequently used surgical technique is heterotopic implantation of the transplant in the iliac fossa, connecting the donor ureter to the recipient bladder. Transplants received from a living donor (e.g., a family member) have a better prognosis than cadaveric kidney transplants (even in the setting of MHC mismatch). For cadaveric kidney transplant recipients, the 1-year survival rate is approx. 88%, while it is 71% at 5 years. For living donor kidney transplant recipients, the 1-year survival rate is approx. 94%, while it is 84% at 5 years. In comparison to hemodialysis, more patients with ESRD who undergo kidney transplantation regain bodily functions, including endocrine function.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with acidosis, electrolyte abnormalities (hyperkalemia), ingestion of toxins (increased BUN), fluid overload (edema), and uremic symptoms (itching of the skin), all of which are indications for dialysis. Although renal replacement therapy is indicated in this patient, peritoneal dialysis would not be the best long-term treatment because of a variety of potential complications that can occur (e.g., infections, metabolic disturbances) if this method is maintained incorrectly and the need for daily, time-consuming treatments.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with CKD require renal replacement therapy (RRT), and hemodialysis is the most commonly used form of RRT in the United States. Although RRT is indicated in this patient and is necessary to bridge the time to definitive treatment, hemodialysis should not be continued as a long-term treatment if another option is available, as hemodialysis is associated with a variety of potential complications (e.g., thrombosis, infection, heart failure) that may impact survival. Moreover, it must be administered at least 3 times per week, which significantly reduces quality of life. A treatment associated with a better survival rate and quality of life should be pursued if available. The 5-year survival rate of the patients on hemodialysis is approx. 30–40% overall, but is only 20% for patients with diabetic nephropathy, which is the likely etiology in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to diabetic nephropathy and presents with fatigue, loss of appetite, pruritus, lower extremity edema, and oliguria. In combination with the patient's hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, uremia, and increased serum creatinine, these features are consistent with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has a kidney transplantation for end-stage renal disease because of long-standing polycystic kidney disease. His postoperative course is uncomplicated. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 5 years ago. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Current medications include basiliximab, mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone. His vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the surgical incisions appear clean and intact. Prior to discharge, administration of which of the following is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While azithromycin would be an appropriate antibiotic for prophylaxis against Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), this is not part of the universal prophylaxis for organ transplant recipients on immunosuppressive therapy. Instead, MAC prophylaxis should only be started for patients infected with HIV with CD4 counts < 50/mm3 when there is a delay in initiating antiretroviral therapy (usually due to patient refusal).

B) CORRECT:

Prophylaxis for opportunistic infections is indicated in severely immunosuppressed patients, such as organ transplant recipients on immunosuppressive drugs or patients with acquired immunodeficiency disorder (AIDS). Universal prophylaxis includes Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and CMV prophylaxis with valganciclovir or ganciclovir. This patient is on immunosuppressive therapy after kidney transplantation and should, therefore, receive both drugs.

C) INCORRECT:

Meningococcal vaccination is indicated routinely for children at age 11 and for adults with an increased risk of exposure (e.g., military recruits, college dorm residents) or severe infection (e.g., asplenia, terminal complement deficiency). This patient's kidney transplant does not place him at elevated risk for Neisseria meningitidis infection. Apart from live vaccines, which are contraindicated for immunosuppressed patients, organ transplant patients should receive all recommended vaccinations.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient is at risk for opportunistic viral infections such as CMV. High-dose oral acyclovir can be used for CMV prophylaxis, but it is not considered first-line and is not part of the universal prophylaxis for organ transplant recipients. Valganciclovir or ganciclovir are recommended first-line treatments for CMV prophylaxis; these agents also decrease the incidence of reactivation of other herpes virus infections.

E) INCORRECT:

While itraconazole would be an appropriate antifungal for prophylaxis against histoplasmosis, this is not part of the universal prophylaxis for organ transplant recipients on immunosuppressive therapy. Rather, histoplasmosis prophylaxis should be started for patients infected with HIV with CD4 counts < 150/mm3 who live in regions hyperendemic for histoplasmosis (e.g., American midwest).

F) INCORRECT:

While inactivated vaccines can be administered as early as 1 month after kidney transplantation, live vaccines, such as the varicella vaccine, are contraindicated in solid-organ transplant recipients.
questions.hint: Prophylaxis against the most common opportunistic pathogens, such as Pneumocystis jirovecii and human cytomegalovirus (CMV), should be administered in posttransplant patients on immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.text: Two weeks after undergoing allogeneic stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma, a 55-year-old man develops a severely pruritic rash, abdominal cramps, and profuse diarrhea. He appears lethargic. Physical examination shows yellow sclerae. There is a generalized maculopapular rash on his face, trunk, and lower extremities, and desquamation of both soles. His serum alanine aminotransferase is 115 U/L, serum aspartate aminotransferase is 97 U/L, and serum total bilirubin is 2.7 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Donor T cells in the graft

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

During allogeneic stem cell transplantation, donor T cells can perceive host tissue as a foreign antigen and mount an immune response, resulting in acute GvHD within 100 days of transplantation. It commonly affects the skin, mucosa, liver, and intestine; thus, patients present with maculopapular rash, diarrhea, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly, as observed in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Newly formed anti-HLA antibodies mediate a humoral immune response in acute graft rejection. Antigen-antibody complexes activate the complement cascade, which mediates tissue injury; hence, complement fragments (C4d) can be observed upon graft tissue staining. Patients with acute graft rejection present with fever, pain in the graft region, and graft vessel vasculitis within 6 months of transplantation. Although this patient presented within 2 weeks of transplantation, he has involvement of intestine, liver, and skin, making acute graft rejection unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Although proliferating transplanted B cells have been shown to have a role in chronic GvHD in studies with animal models, its role in patients with allogeneic stem cell transplantation is not well defined. Chronic GvHD is observed 100 days after transplantation and presents with clinical features of chronic enteritis, chronic sicca syndrome, bronchiolitis obliterans, liver dysfunction, and polymyositis.

D) INCORRECT:

Exposure to graft MHC alloantigen can activate recipient T cells, which orchestrates a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction (cell-mediated immune response), that develops into acute graft rejection within weeks to months. Patients present with fever, graft tissue swelling, generalized deterioration, and lymphocytic infiltration of graft vessels; although this patient presented within 2 weeks of transplantation, his symptoms are not confined to the transplanted tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Preformed cytotoxic anti-HLA antibodies react to graft class 1 HLA antigen and mediate hyperacute graft rejection, which is commonly seen in cases with donor recipient ABO incompatibility. Antigen-antibody complexes activate the complement system (type 2 hypersensitivity reaction), leading to thrombus formation and graft ischemia. Patients present with intraoperative graft swelling and can develop systemic inflammatory response syndrome within minutes to hours, unlike this patient who presented 2 weeks after transplantation with maculopapular rash, diarrhea, and features of liver injury.
questions.hint: This patient developed a desquamating pruritic rash, diarrhea with abdominal cramping, and evidence of liver damage (scleral jaundice, elevated transaminases) shortly after a stem cell transplantation, which is concerning for graft-versus-host disease (GvHD).

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia comes to the physician because she has not had a menstrual period for 12 months. Menarche occurred at the age of 11 years, and menses occurred at regular 28-day intervals until they became irregular 1 year ago. Physical examination shows normal female genitalia and bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated FSH levels consistent with premature ovarian failure. Fluorescence in situ hybridization studies show a 46,XY karyotype in the peripheral blood cells. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the male karyotype found on chromosomal analysis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Allogeneic stem cell transplantation is used in post-remission therapy of patients with ALL who have a high risk of relapse. In contrast to autologous stem cell transplantation, which involves the removal, storage, and retransfusion of a patient's own cells, allogenous stem cell transplantation refers to the administration of hematopoietic stem cells from a sibling or unrelated donor. Chromosomal analysis in this female patient shows a male genotype (46,XY karyotype) because she received stem cells from a male donor (e.g., sex-mismatched transplantation). This patient's premature ovarian failure is most likely related to cytotoxic effects of chemotherapy and radiation administered prior to the allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

Other types of grafts include isografts (e.g., from an identical twin) and xenografts (e.g., from a pig).

B) INCORRECT:

Müllerian duct agenesis (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome) is a rare, congenital defect that manifests with normally functioning gonads, female phenotype, and primary amenorrhea due to a missing or abnormal uterus. In contrast to this patient, premature ovarian failure and male genotype on FISH analysis would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

21-hydroxylase deficiency is seen in patients with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), a group of autosomal recessive defects in the enzymes responsible for cortisol, aldosterone, and androgen synthesis. In contrast to this patient, 21-hydroxylase deficiency in women most commonly manifests with hypotension, virilization, and precocious puberty. Although menstrual irregularities can occur in CAH, the mechanism differs from premature ovarian failure. It would not explain the male genotype seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiation is used as CNS preventive therapy in patients with ALL, and it has been associated with amenorrhea and premature ovarian failure due to cytotoxic effects on oocytes. However, radiotherapy of the CNS would not cause a male genotype on FISH, which is seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Defective androgen receptor function is the underlying cause of androgen insensitivity syndrome, an X-linked recessive mutation of the gene locus encoding the androgen receptor. Patients present with amenorrhea, variable degrees of feminization, and a 46,XY karyotype. However, a blind vaginal pouch, uterine agenesis, and primary amenorrhea (rather than secondary amenorrhea) would also be expected.
questions.hint: This woman with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) has secondary amenorrhea due to premature ovarian failure, most likely related to chemotherapy she received in the past. Physical examination shows a female phenotype, whereas chromosomal analysis shows a male genotype.

questions.text: Two weeks after undergoing an allogeneic skin graft procedure for extensive full-thickness burns involving his left leg, a 41-year-old man develops redness and swelling over the graft site. He has not had any fevers or chills. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F). Physical examination of the left lower leg shows well-demarcated erythema and edema around the skin graft site. The graft site is minimally tender and there is no exudate. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s skin condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Complement activation through the alternative pathway occurs in direct response to microbial cell surface molecules (e.g., bacterial endotoxins) rather than the formation of the antigen-antibody complex seen in the classic pathway. However, the absence of purulent discharge, tenderness, and fever makes this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

IgE-mediated mast cell activation is the mechanism underlying type I hypersensitivity reactions (including anaphylaxis). Patients typically present immediately after exposure to an antigen with dyspnea, bronchospasm, hypotension, flushing, urticaria, pruritus, and/or abdominal pain. Examples of type I HSR include anaphylaxis, most drug allergies, and food allergies. This patient' s transplant rejection is caused by a different mechanism.

C) INCORRECT:

Immune complex-mediated complement activation is the mechanism of a type III hypersensitivity reaction, which is characterized by the deposition of IgG-antigen complexes in various tissues. Examples of type III HSR include polyarteritis nodosa, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, IgA nephropathy, and lupus nephritis. This patient's recent history of an allogeneic graft placement raises concern for a different mechanism of inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of surgical site infection > 4 days postoperatively. However, the absence of purulent discharge, tenderness, and fever makes this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Preformed antibody-mediated complement activation is the underlying mechanism of hyperacute transplant rejection, during which IgM and IgG antibodies bind to self-antigens that are mistakenly identified as foreign. This process triggers complement activation and inflammation. Hyperacute transplant rejection is an example of a type II HSR and typically presents with swelling, erythema, and sloughing at the site of the graft in the immediate postoperative period. This patient presents two weeks after graft placement making a hyperacute rejection unlikely.

F) CORRECT:

Th1 cell-induced macrophage activation is responsible for this patient's acute graft rejection. This type IV hypersensitivity reaction is triggered by foreign antigens from the allogeneic skin graft, which incite host T-cell sensitization. Continued exposure to the foreign antigen causes the pre-sensitized T cells to activate macrophages and thus induce an inflammatory reaction in the tissue. In addition, this exposure leads to antibody-mediated complement activation (similar to hyperacute transplant rejection), during which IgM and IgG antibodies develop in response to foreign antigens from an allogeneic graft. This reaction most commonly presents as redness, swelling, itching, and tissue sloughing at the graft site.

Treatment involves removal of the graft and replacement with an autologous graft, which would not incite such an immune response.
questions.hint: Pain and edema within 6 months of receiving an allogeneic skin graft are signs of acute graft rejection.

questions.text: Two hours after undergoing allogeneic kidney transplantation for polycystic kidney disease, a 14-year-old girl has lower abdominal pain. Examination shows tenderness to palpation in the area the donor kidney was placed. Ultrasound of the donor kidney shows diffuse tissue edema. Serum creatinine begins to increase and dialysis is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: T-lymphocyte activation by donor HLA peptides
Preformed antibodies against class I HLA molecules
Irreversible intimal fibrosis and obstruction of vessels
Immune complex deposition in donor tissue

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Host T-lymphocyte activation by donor HLA peptides mediates a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction (cell-mediated immune response), leading to acute graft rejection. Patients present with fever, graft tissue swelling, generalized deterioration, and lymphocytic infiltration of graft vessels. However, acute rejection usually occurs weeks to months after transplantation, not within hours.

B) INCORRECT:

Proliferation of donor T lymphocytes can be seen in graft vs. host disease (GVHD), in which donor T cells perceive host tissue as a foreign antigen and mount an immune response. GVHD primarily occurs in allogeneic stem cell transplantation, not kidney transplantation. Moreover, patients commonly present with maculopapular rash, diarrhea, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly, not graft swelling within hours of transplantation.

C) CORRECT:

Hyperacute graft rejection is mediated by preformed cytotoxic antibodies against donor class I HLA molecules or donor blood group antigens (type 2 hypersensitivity reactions). Antigen-antibody binding activates the complement system, leading to thrombus formation and graft ischemia. Patients present with graft swelling and deterioration of organ function within 48 hours of the transplant. Hyperacute rejections can be prevented by cross-matching and ABO group matching before organ transplantation.

D) INCORRECT:

Irreversible intimal fibrosis and obstruction of graft vessels are seen in chronic graft rejection, which is characterized by slow and progressive loss of organ function that typically occurs several months to years after organ transplantation. Hyperacute graft failure has a different cause.

E) INCORRECT:

In type 3 hypersensitivity reactions, deposition of circulating immune complexes activates the complement system and recruits inflammatory cells, which leads to tissue damage. This is the underlying mechanism in serum sickness, Henoch-Schönlein purpura, and poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. However, type 3 hypersensitivity does not play a role in graft rejection.
questions.hint: This patient appears to be rejecting the donor kidney. When rejection occurs less than 48 hours after transplantation, it is termed hyperacute rejection.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of fatigue, generalized itching, and yellowing of the eyes and skin. He underwent a liver transplantation because of acute liver failure following α-amanitin poisoning 1 year ago. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and abdominal distention with shifting dullness. A liver biopsy specimen shows decreased hepatic duct density. Further histological examination of the liver biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute rejection occurs within 6 months of transplantation and is due to antibody formation against donor MHCs. It is characterized histologically by vasculitic changes of the graft vessels and an interstitial lymphocytic infiltrate. The timing of the patient's symptoms is inconsistent with acute rejection, as is the biopsy finding of ductopenia.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatocellular carcinoma may manifest with liver failure, as seen in this patient. However, the incidence of HCC in transplant recipients is only increased in those who were previously diagnosed with HCC, or in those who have recurrent viral hepatitis. Furthermore, HCC is not associated with ductopenia, as seen on this patient's liver biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperacute rejection occurs within 48 hours of organ transplantation and is due to the reaction of pre-existing antibodies against donor antigens, leading to complement activation and widespread thrombosis and necrosis. It is characterized histologically by fibrinoid necrosis, vessel thrombosis, and tissue ischemia. The timing of the patient's symptoms and ductopenia on biopsy is inconsistent with hyperacute rejection.

D) CORRECT:

Signs and symptoms of liver failure one year after liver transplantation suggests chronic graft rejection, which occurs due to reactions at both the cellular and humoral level in response to donor peptides. The ensuing inflammation leads to interstitial fibrosis, atrophy of the parenchyma, vascular smooth muscle proliferation, and ductopenia (as seen on this patient's biopsy).

E) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus infection is an important cause of transplant failure in the first 6 months, due to iatrogenic immunosuppression to prevent transplant rejection and subsequent seroconversion (e.g., if the patient was initially seronegative but received a graft from a seropositive donor) or reactivation of the virus. CMV infection typically manifests with fever, malaise, and hepatitis, similarly to acute transplant rejection. A liver biopsy would show viral inclusions, a mononuclear cell infiltrate, and microabscesses. This patient's timeline of hepatic failure one year after transplant makes a different cause and associated finding more likely.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of liver transplantation is now exhibiting features of liver failure (jaundice, pruritus, fatigue, ascites). Biopsy shows ductopenia, which indicates vanishing bile duct syndrome.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of progressively worsening fatigue and loss of appetite. Five years ago, he received a kidney transplant from a living family member. Current medications include sirolimus and mycophenolate. His blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show normocytic, normochromic anemia and a serum creatinine concentration of 3.1 mg/dL; his vital signs and laboratory studies were normal 6 months ago. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient’s increase in creatinine concentration?

choices.text: CD8+ T cell-mediated parenchymal cell damage
Donor T cell-mediated epithelial cell damage
Donor endothelial cell damage by preformed host antibodies
CD4+ T cell-mediated intimal smooth muscle proliferation
Reactivation of a latent BK virus infection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CD8+ T cell-mediated parenchymal cell damage to the transplanted organ causes acute organ rejection. This is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction in which donor MHC antigens activate the host's immune system, leading to vasculitic damage in the grafted organ. Acute rejection most often manifests with fever, flank pain, and new-onset edema; laboratory studies show a decrease in renal functionality. This process occurs within weeks to months of the transplantation, so it would be extremely unlikely for this patient to have acute organ rejection years after his operation.

B) INCORRECT:

Donor T cell-mediated epithelial cell damage to the host's tissue is consistent with graft-versus-host disease (GvHD). GvHD is caused by immunocompetent T cells in the graft that recognize recipient cells as foreign via a type IV hypersensitivity mechanism. This leads to profound multiorgan dysfunction in the host that can manifest either acutely or chronically. This patient, however, has isolated dysfunction of the transplanted organ, not of his native organs. Moreover, GvHD is usually seen in hematopoietic stem cell or liver transplantation, but only rarely in kidney transplantation.

C) INCORRECT:

Donor endothelial cell damage by preformed host antibodies is the mechanism underlying hyperacute rejection. Damage to the transplanted organ's endothelium leads to rapid-onset thrombosis and graft ischemia, ultimately causing graft necrosis. Hyperacute rejection occurs within 48 hours after transplantation, most often within minutes. Failure of an organ years later, as seen in this patient, cannot be attributed to hyperacute rejection.

D) CORRECT:

Intimal smooth muscle proliferation mediated by CD4+ T cells is one of the histopathological hallmarks of chronic organ rejection. The release of cytokines by host CD4+ T cells induces a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which damages the donor organ. Consequences of this injury include arteriosclerosis due to intimal smooth muscle proliferation and interstitial fibrosis with atrophic changes of the organ parenchyma. Chronic rejection of a transplanted organ is an irreversible reaction that usually occurs a few years, and no earlier than 6 months, after transplantation. It typically causes slow, progressive loss of organ function, which manifests with slowly rising serum creatinine and new-onset hypertension and anemia, as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced tubular vacuolization can result from chronic therapy with calcineurin inhibitors such as tacrolimus. Chronic tacrolimus nephrotoxicity would also involve progressive kidney dysfunction and increased serum creatinine, which this patient presents with. However, this patient's regimen of sirolimus and mycophenolate is not nephrotoxic.

F) INCORRECT:

Reactivation of a latent BK virus infection can cause polyomavirus-associated nephropathy, which manifests with progressive renal dysfunction (e.g., elevated serum creatinine and hypertension, which this patient has). Unlike here, it also commonly involves hematuria. BK nephropathy most frequently occurs 10–13 months after transplantation, though there are occasional reports of late-onset cases. Although this is a possible etiology of this patient's presentation, it is not the most likely explanation.
questions.hint: This patient's hypertension and diminished renal function 5 years post-transplant suggest chronic transplant rejection.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of shortness of breath and dry cough. Eight weeks ago, she received a lung transplant from an unrelated donor. Current medications include prednisone, cyclosporine, and azathioprine. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F). Physical examination is unremarkable other than a well-healed surgical scar. Pulmonary function tests show a decline in FEV1 and FVC compared to values from several weeks ago. Histological examination of a lung biopsy specimen shows perivascular and interstitial lymphocytic infiltrates with bronchiolar inflammation. This patient's condition is most likely caused by T cell sensitization against which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Donor ABO antigens can stimulate hyperacute rejection. In cases of ABO incompatibility, preformed antibodies against non-host ABO antigens will stimulate a rapid rejection event, which will induce widespread graft thrombosis, leading to ischemic necrosis of the transplanted organ. However, this would occur in the first minutes to hours after transplantation, not several weeks later, as seen in this patient. Also, the histological examination would show neutrophilic infiltration with fibrinoid necrosis, not lymphocytic infiltrates.

B) CORRECT:

Acute transplant rejection is caused by acquired cellular (type IV HSR) and humoral (type II HSR) immunity. Type IV HSR is mediated by both CD4+ and CD8+ T cells. Donor antigens in the transplanted lung present on MHC class II of the host's antigen-presenting cells (APCs) stimulate CD4 T cells, which subsequently differentiate into Th1 cells. Proliferating Th1 cells release proinflammatory cytokine (e.g., interferon-gamma) that stimulates the infiltration of macrophages into the vasculature and graft parenchyma. Likewise, expression of MHC class I on donor cells stimulates host CD8 T cells, leading to a direct CD8-mediated cytotoxic damage in the donor cells. Type II HSR results from the production of IgM and/or IgG antibodies, which bind donor antigens on the transplanted lung and induce complement-dependent or independent death of donor cells.

C) INCORRECT:

Recipient MHC class I antigens play a role in the development of graft-versus-host disease. Immunocompetent T cells in the donor tissue (most often in bone marrow or liver transplants) can recognize host antigens displayed on antigen presenting cells as foreign antigens, causing these donor T cells to stimulate an inflammatory response. However, this would lead to multiorgan failure in the host, which this patient shows no signs of. This patient's symptoms and time frame since surgery suggest a different cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Donor rhesus D antigen can lead to hyperacute rejection in cases of Rh incompatibility. Preformed host antibodies against the donor D antigen activate the complement cascade, leading to rapid-onset thrombosis of the donor organ's vasculature and subsequent ischemic necrosis. However, the timeframe for this form of type II hypersensitivity reaction is typically within minutes of organ transplantation and would not be expected weeks after surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

CMV glycoprotein B antigen would elicit a T cell response in the case of CMV pneumonitis. This is the second most common infectious complication following lung transplantation (bacterial pneumonia being the most common). CMV pneumonitis can also cause a low-grade fever, cough, and changes in pulmonary function tests. However, a biopsy would show intracellular inclusion bodies in pneumocytes, not perivascular and interstitial lymphocytic infiltrates.
questions.hint: In light of her recent lung transplant, this patient's symptoms (low-grade fever, shortness of breath, cough), decline in pulmonary function test, and lung biopsy findings (perivascular and interstitial lymphocytic infiltrates) suggest acute graft rejection. Acute transplant rejection is the most common form of solid organ transplant rejection.

questions.text: An investigator studying immune-mediated pulmonary damage performs an autopsy on a bilateral lung transplant recipient who died of hypercapnic respiratory failure. The patient underwent lung transplantation for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Microscopic examination of the lung shows diffuse eosinophilic scarring of the terminal and respiratory bronchioles and near-complete luminal obliteration by polypoidal plugs of granulation tissue. Examination of the skin shows no abnormalities. The findings in this patient are most consistent with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is caused by infusions of donor-derived, anti-host antibodies within any plasma-containing transfusion products (e.g., IVIG, cryoprecipitate). The injury occurs within six hours of transfusion and causes pulmonary edema, dyspnea, and fever, which can occasionally progress to acute respiratory distress syndrome. It is possible that this patient received blood products and developed a TRALI that led to his death. However, an autopsy would show hyaline membranes, neutrophil accumulation, and hemosiderin-laden macrophages, none of which lead here.

B) INCORRECT:

Recurrence of the primary disease (idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis) is rare after lung transplantation. If the condition were to recur, biopsies would show fibrosis with disorganized collagen, excess extracellular matrix deposition, and cystic features.
Image Description:

CT chest (lung window; a: axial plane; b: coronal plane) of a patient with progressive dyspnea on exertion

Extensive reticular interstitial thickening with honeycombing (examples indicated by green outlines) is accompanied by traction bronchiectasis (examples indicated by red arrows). The distribution is subpleural and basal predominant. The appearance is diagnostic of a usual interstitial pneumonia pattern. There are no CT features to suggest an alternative diagnosis.

DA: descending aorta; H: heart

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperacute graft rejection is a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction caused by pre-existing host antibodies against donor antigens. The reaction typically occurs within minutes to hours of organ transplantation and causes acute thrombosis, edema, and, ultimately, necrosis of the graft. The pathological findings of bronchiolitis obliterans would not be seen in cases of hyperacute rejection.

D) CORRECT:

Chronic graft rejection of the lungs usually occurs six months or more after transplantation and typically manifests as bronchiolitis obliterans. Chronic rejection is caused by a combination of type 2 hypersensitivity and type 4 hypersensitivity reactions that ultimately result in host CD4+ T cells recognizing donor peptides as foreign. An immune response that targets airway submucosa is subsequently triggered. Repeated inflammation and granulation of the airways eventually leads to obliteration of the lumen and failure of the graft. Hypercapnic respiratory failure is a common complication of bronchiolitis obliterans that is caused by poor gas exchange.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute graft-versus-host disease is due to immunocompetent donor T-cell proliferation within the host, in which donor T cells recognize host tissue as foreign antigens and mount a type 4 hypersensitivity response. Patients often present with maculopapular rashes, jaundice, nausea, and vomiting, which progress to multiorgan failure. The lack of cutaneous findings on physical examination and histopathological analysis makes this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, acute GvHD does not cause bronchiolitis obliterans, which occurs as a result of more chronic inflammation.

F) INCORRECT:

Acute graft rejection is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction against a donor organ. The reaction begins as early as one week after the transplantation, with the highest risk of the event occurring within the first six months. Although acute rejection can lead to respiratory failure and death, the expected histological findings would be widespread vasculitis of the graft vessels accompanied by heterogeneous mononuclear aggregates, not bronchiolitis obliterans.
questions.hint: The histopathological findings in this patient suggest bronchiolitis obliterans, a type of obstructive lung disease associated with hypercapnic respiratory failure.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss over the past 2 months. He also noticed yellowing of his eyes over the last week. Seven months ago, he underwent orthotopic liver transplantation because of alcoholic cirrhosis. He has a history of hepatitis C infection and hypertension. He used to drink alcohol excessively during his twenties, but he has not consumed alcohol for the past 10 years. His current medications are tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, prednisone, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, hydrochlorothiazide, amlodipine, and lisinopril. He had also received glecaprevir, pibrentasvir, and ganciclovir for the first 3 months after transplantation. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 152/98 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. Laboratory studies show:



On admission
2 months ago



Hemoglobin
10.5 g/dL
11.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4300/mm3

3900/mm3



Platelet count
57,000/mm3

63,000/mm3



Serum




Total bilirubin
2.7 mg/dL
1.5 mg/dL


Aspartate aminotransferase
85
34


Alanine aminotransferase
76
44


Alkaline phosphatase
140
67



Liver biopsy shows perivenular fibrosis, intimal inflammation, and loss of bile ducts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In rare cases, hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) can arise de-novo in the transplanted liver and manifest similarly with fatigue, weight loss, elevated hepatic transaminases, worsening hyperbilirubinemia, and possibly even elevated alkaline phosphatase. In addition, HCV infection is a risk factor for HCC, and post-transplant immunosuppressive therapy increases the risk of post-transplant malignancies. However, this patient was treated with the direct-acting antiviral glecaprevir/pibrentasvir, which has a very high rate of sustained virologic response. Moreover, de-novo HCC typically arises several years after transplantation rather than within a few months, and this patient's liver biopsy does not show any evidence of malignancy. Examples of more common post-transplant malignancies are nonmelanona skin cancers (e.g., cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma), Kaposi sarcoma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Pathogens that are typically implicated in infection of the liver graft are cytomegalovirus (CMV), Ebstein-Barr virus (EBV), human herpes virus 6 (HHV-6), and the hepatitis C virus (HCV). If HCV infection is not treated, the grafted liver is almost always reinfected; HCV infection of the graft can cause fibrosing cholestatic hepatitis (FCH), which would manifest with similar clinical features, laboratory findings, evidence of fibrosis and, occasionally, hepatic ductopenia on biopsy within a few months of liver transplantation. However, FCH is characterized by periportal fibrosis and/or pericellular fibrosis rather than perivenular fibrosis, and other findings such as hepatocyte swelling would be seen. Moreover, this patient was treated with the direct-acting antiviral glecaprevir/pibrentasvir, which has a very high rate of sustained virologic response. Hepatic CMV, EBV, or HHV-6 infection does not cause fibrosis or ductopenia in the liver graft. CMV infection is also less likely because the patient received ganciclovir prophylaxis.

C) INCORRECT:

A graft-versus-host disease (GvHD) can occur following liver transplantation as a result of donor T lymphocytes in the transplanted liver and manifest with fatigue and weight loss. The onset of symptoms more than 100 days after transplantation is consistent with the chronic form of GvHD. However, patients with chronic GvHD would also have skin changes (e.g., scleroderma-like rash, xerostomia), gastrointestinal symptoms due to chronic enteritis, and respiratory symptoms due to bronchiolitis obliterans, which are not reported by this patient. Hepatic dysfunction and hepatic ductopenia, which are seen here, can occur with chronic GvHD due to nonhepatic grafts (e.g., allogeneic bone marrow transplantation, small bowel transplantation) but would not be seen with hepatic transplantation.

D) CORRECT:

A chronic transplant rejection is damage to the graft by the host's immune system that usually occurs several months after transplantation. There is no clear cut-off value because the diagnosis of a chronic versus acute transplant rejection is based on biopsy findings; 6 months is an approximation. The pathophysiology of chronic graft rejection is not completely understood, but a host T cell-mediated response is believed to play a role. Chronic hepatic allograft rejection manifests with progressive hepatic dysfunction and cholestasis. On a liver biopsy, fibrosis and hepatic ductopenia are the most common findings. Obliterative arteriopathy, which is characteristic of chronic rejection of other allografts, is usually less evident because it mainly affects larger perihilar arteries. When compared to acute transplant rejection, post-transplant immunosuppression is less effective at preventing chronic transplant rejection. In most cases, patients with chronic transplant rejection will require retransplantation.

See “Types of graft rejection” table.

E) INCORRECT:

An acute transplant rejection would manifest similarly with fatigue, weight loss, elevated hepatic transaminases, elevated alkaline phosphatase, worsening hyperbilirubinemia, and possibly even hepatic ductopenia due to bile duct destruction. However, an acute rejection typically occurs within days or weeks of transplantation, unlike in this patient who developed hepatic dysfunction after several months. Moreover, a liver biopsy in patients with acute hepatic graft rejection would show dense lymphocytic infiltration and necrotizing vasculitis; fibrosis, as seen here, would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

The primary disease for which liver transplantation was performed (i.e., alcoholic cirrhosis) would not recur in this patient because he completely abstains from drinking alcohol. His other primary disease, hepatitis C, could progress more rapidly following transplantation because of immunosuppressive therapy. In this case, progressively worsening hepatitis C would lead to fibrosing cholestatic hepatitis and present with similar clinical features, laboratory findings, and biopsy findings within a few months of liver transplantation. However, this patient was treated with the direct-acting antiviral glecaprevir/pibrentasvir, which has a very high rate of sustained virologic response.
questions.hint: The loss of bile ducts seen on this patient’s liver biopsy is known as vanishing bile duct syndrome. This patient's underlying diagnosis can also occur after other types of transplantation. Following heart transplantation, for example, the characteristic pathologic finding is accelerated coronary arteriosclerosis.

questions.text:
Six weeks after undergoing an allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation for Fanconi anemia, a 9-year-old girl develops cramping abdominal pain, watery diarrhea, and a painful skin rash. Current medications include cyclosporine, mycophenolate mofetil, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and valacyclovir. She appears lethargic but is oriented to time, place, and person. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination shows yellow sclerae and dry mucous membranes. There is a maculopapular rash over the ear lobes, upper back, palms, and soles. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4100/mm3



Platelet count
110,000/mm3



Serum



Total bilirubin
5 mg/dL


Aspartate aminotransferase
100 U/L


Alanine aminotransferase
120 U/L


Alkaline phosphatase
300 U/L


Test of the stool for occult blood is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection can manifest with symptoms of colitis (e.g., diarrhea, cramping abdominal pain), elevated liver enzymes, and pancytopenia in immunosuppressed individuals following hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. However, CMV would not explain the maculopapular rash seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DRESS syndrome) typically manifests 1–8 weeks after the initiation of a high-risk medication such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and can manifest with a maculopapular rash, hepatic dysfunction, and thrombocytopenia. However, patients with DRESS syndrome typically have diffuse lymphadenopathy, and gastrointestinal involvement is uncommon.

C) INCORRECT:

Hepatic venoocclusive disease can develop following hematopoietic stem cell transplantation due to chemotherapy exposure and often manifests with jaundice, abdominal pain, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes. However, this disease is also commonly associated with evidence of fluid overload (e.g., unexplained weight gain, dyspnea, ascites) and hepatomegaly. Moreover, hepatic venoocclusive disease is not associated with diarrhea or a painful maculopapular rash.

D) CORRECT:

Acute graft-versus-host disease typically occurs after transplantations of lymphocyte-rich organs (e.g., allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation) and develops within the first 100 days following the procedure. Donor T lymphocytes trigger a type IV hypersensitivity reaction in the host organs, leading to severe organ damage. Skin, liver, and intestine are commonly affected, so patients present with a maculopapular rash, diarrhea, abdominal pain, jaundice, and cholestatic liver dysfunction. Hematopoietic involvement may also be present (anemia, thrombocytopenia, leukocytopenia).

E) INCORRECT:

Posttransplant lymphoproliferative disease (PTLD) typically occurs due to Epstein-Barr virus reactivation in patients with severe immunosuppression following solid organ transplantation or allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. PTLD can manifest with abdominal pain and liver dysfunction. However, PTLD is also commonly associated with mononucleosis-like symptoms such as weight loss, fatigue, and lymphadenopathy.

F) INCORRECT:

Engraftment syndrome occurs during neutrophil recovery following a hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) and can manifest with skin rash, hepatic dysfunction, jaundice, and diarrhea. However, it occurs within 3–4 days of engraftment, which happens within 2–4 weeks following HSCT. Engraftment has already occurred in this patient, as evidenced by her high leukocyte count. In addition, engraftment syndrome is often associated with features of a capillary leak such as pulmonary edema and encephalopathy.
questions.hint: Biopsy of the involved areas will show endothelial damage and lymphocytic infiltration.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old man who underwent orthotopic heart transplantation 18 months ago for treatment of a nonischemic cardiomyopathy presents to the emergency department with 5 days of progressive dyspnea on exertion, orthopnea, and palpitations. His mother, who accompanies him, says that his last endomyocardial biopsy, performed 6 months ago, showed no evidence of rejection and that her son adheres to his immunosuppressive medications.
His temperature is 36.8°C, his heart rate is 136 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 102/80 mm Hg, his respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 92% while he is breathing ambient air. He has an S3 gallop and rales in both lung fields.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A chest radiograph reveals pulmonary vascular congestion. An electrocardiogram is obtained (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute allograft rejection after heart transplantation is an urgent, time-sensitive entity requiring treatment (e.g., intensification of the immunosuppressive regimen). Patients are at increased risk for rejection if they are young, female, or Black; the donor is female; or there is a higher number of HLA mismatches between the donor and the recipient. Acute allograft rejection typically manifests with left ventricular dysfunction, resulting in acute heart failure or even cardiogenic shock. Atrial arrhythmias, including atrial flutter and atrial fibrillation, are not uncommon.

Key learning point: Acute heart failure symptoms and atrial arrhythmias in a young patient within 2 years after orthotopic heart transplantation should raise suspicion for acute allograft rejection.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonischemic cardiomyopathy is usually a result of exposure to toxins (e.g., alcohol or chemotherapy), a congenital genetic disorder, or a viral infection. No toxin exposure has occurred since transplantation, and a genetic condition, if present initially, would not recur in a transplanted heart. A viral etiology is a possibility, but this is much less common than acute rejection, and the patient did not have symptoms suggestive of a preceding viral illness.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac allograft vasculopathy, also known as cardiac transplant vasculopathy, occurs as a result of diffuse intimal hyperplasia of the intramural and epicardial coronary arteries due to immunologic mechanisms. It typically progresses slowly. It is detectable by angiography in 8% of cardiac transplantation survivors within the first year, in 32% within the first 5 years, and in 43% within the first 8 years after transplantation. Beyond the first year, cardiac allograft vasculopathy is the second most common cause of death (after cancer).

D) INCORRECT:

Tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy is plausible in a patient with chronic atrial flutter and a rapid ventricular response, but this patient’s acute symptoms are more suggestive of rejection.

E) INCORRECT:

The electrocardiogram does not show manifestations suggestive of acute myocardial infarction (e.g., ST-segment elevation or Q waves).

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease who is receiving supplemental oxygen (4 liters per minute) presents for follow-up after having been hospitalized a week earlier for an exacerbation of her chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. During that hospitalization, she required noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation for treatment of hypercapnic respiratory failure. She reports feeling much better but is still mildly short of breath and is completing a glucocorticoid taper. Her medications are tiotropium bromide, inhaled fluticasone, and inhaled salmeterol. She is currently enrolled in pulmonary rehabilitation.
Baseline pulmonary function tests reveal an FEV1 of 0.45 liters (17% of predicted), an FVC of 0.81 liters (31% of predicted), and an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 56%. The diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide is 7% of predicted.
Which one of the following long-term strategies is most appropriate for managing this patient’s chronic lung disease?

choices.text: Increase supplemental oxygen use to 6 liters per minute
Refer for workup for lung transplantation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Omalizumab is used to treat moderate-to-severe persistent asthma but not COPD.

B) INCORRECT:

An increase in supplemental oxygen use would not be helpful and could be detrimental.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic prednisone therapy does not have well-established benefits in patients with COPD and has a substantial side-effect profile.

D) INCORRECT:

Lung-volume-reduction surgery is not an option when the diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide is <20% of predicted.

E) CORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is the most common indication for lung transplantation in adults. Patients with severe COPD should be considered for lung transplantation if they have a post-bronchodilator FEV1 that is <25% of predicted, a baseline partial pressure of carbon dioxide that is >50 mm Hg, or COPD-associated pulmonary arterial hypertension/cor pulmonale. Patients with COPD who require oxygen supplementation and exhibit progressive deterioration should also be referred for possible lung transplantation, according to the American Thoracic Society and the European Respiratory Society.

In patients with chronic lung disease of this severity, palliative care consultation is also always reasonable to consider. This consultation can be done in conjunction with referral for lung transplantation evaluation because focusing on relief of symptoms and goals of care can happen at the same time.

Key learning point: Patients with end-stage lung disease on maximal medical therapy should be referred for evaluation for possible lung transplantation.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with a history of cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use is hospitalized for worsening ascites and encephalopathy. She has a history of obesity and a current BMI of 35. One month before admission, she underwent abdominal ultrasound that showed a 3-cm lesion in the right lobe of the liver, and MRI confirmed that the lesion was consistent with a single focus of hepatocellular carcinoma with no evidence of metastatic spread.
She underwent a partial colectomy 8 years ago for localized colon cancer. A colonoscopy one year ago showed no evidence of recurrent disease.
The patient is married and lives with her husband and child. She drank half a pint of vodka per day for 20 years but quit drinking one month ago.
