On admission, her abdomen is distended, and shifting dullness is present. She has a temperature of 38.9°C, a blood pressure of 80/50 mm Hg, a heart rate of 130 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 89% while breathing ambient air.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Laboratory evaluation yields the following results:



Patient Value
Reference Range



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
20,000
4500–11,000


International normalized ratio
1.8
—


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
5.0
0.3–1.0


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.1
0.6–1.1


The patient is rapidly intubated, and a chest radiograph reveals pneumonia in the right lower lobe. Vasopressors and broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated.
Which one of the following components of the patient's history and presentation is an absolute contraindication to liver transplantation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prior malignancy is not an absolute contraindication to liver transplantation. A mandatory 2- to 5-year tumor-free period is required after curative therapy for a malignancy.

B) CORRECT:

There are several absolute and relative contraindications to liver transplantation. Although the specific contraindications vary according to the policies of each individual transplant center, typical contraindications include:

• Brain death
• Uncontrolled infection or sepsis
• Severe cardiopulmonary disease
• AIDS
• Inadequate social support or inability to adhere to medications
• Certain anatomical abnormalities that make surgery technically difficult
• Grade 3 obesity (BMI ≥40)
• Active extrahepatic malignancy
• Hepatocellular carcinoma with metastatic spread

Many transplant centers have historically enforced a 6-month minimum period of abstinence from alcohol and illicit substance use before transplantation, to allow clinicians and patients time to address the substance use disorder and to allow patients with acute alcoholic hepatitis (AAH) to perhaps spontaneously recover, thereby obviating the need for liver transplantation. However, such policies have become more flexible over time, as several studies have shown dramatically improved survival rates among patients receiving liver transplants for AAH. Most of the benefit in these patients was achieved in the first month, thereby confirming the utility of early transplantation in select AAH patients who do not respond to glucocorticoids.

Key learning point: Medical contraindications to liver transplantation include sepsis or uncontrolled infection, severe cardiopulmonary disease, grade 3 obesity, and active extrahepatic malignancies.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no specific age cutoff for liver transplantation, although patients over age 65 have lower rates of 1- and 5-year survival than younger patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Grade 3 obesity (BMI ≥40) is typically a contraindication to liver transplantation.

E) INCORRECT:

Liver transplantation is the treatment of choice for hepatocellular carcinoma. Patients with a single lesion <5 cm or three lesions <3 cm without radiographic evidence of extrahepatic disease are candidates for transplantation.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman reports a 3-day history of nonbloody diarrhea 45 days after undergoing allogeneic bone marrow transplantation for acute myeloid leukemia. She also reports symptoms of nausea and vomiting.
On examination, she is afebrile, and her abdomen is slightly tender throughout.
Her leukocyte count is normal. Stool cultures, stool examination for ova and parasites, Gram stain, Clostridioides difficile testing, fecal occult-blood testing, and stains for Cryptosporidium are negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Campylobacter infection may manifest with diarrhea but is typically found on routine stool culture.

B) INCORRECT:

Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli infection manifests with bloody diarrhea, often with evidence of renal dysfunction and hemolysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Typhlitis (neutropenic enterocolitis) typically develops 10 to 14 days after chemotherapy in patients with profound neutropenia and is characterized by abdominal distention, nausea, vomiting, and watery or bloody diarrhea.

D) CORRECT:

The most typical causes of diarrhea after bone marrow transplantation are graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and infection. Acute GVHD traditionally occurs within 100 days after bone marrow transplantation. The gastrointestinal tract is the second most commonly involved organ system in GVHD. Symptoms include nausea, vomiting, pain, and diarrhea. The diagnosis of GVHD is made with endoscopic gastrointestinal biopsies.

Any transplant recipient undergoing evaluation for diarrhea should first have infectious causes ruled out. Biopsies for cytomegalovirus infection should be performed, followed by rectosigmoid biopsies, as they have the highest sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value for diagnosing GVHD.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of nausea, vomiting, and nonbloody diarrhea in a patient who recently received an allogeneic bone marrow transplant and has negative stool studies, a negative stool examination for ova and parasites, and a normal leukocyte count is acute graft-versus-host disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Giardia infection is a common cause of watery diarrhea. Giardia is readily detected on a routine stool examination for ova and parasites.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with hepatitis C virus infection undergoes an uncomplicated, orthotopic liver transplantation. On postoperative day 7, while still hospitalized, he develops a fever of 38.3°C and has four episodes of diarrhea. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. He had received antibiotics for 2 days around the time of the surgery. Serologic tests for cytomegalovirus in the organ donor were negative.
The patient's physical examination is unremarkable except for minimal incisional tenderness, which is unchanged and not associated with erythema, warmth, or purulence. He has new leukocytosis, indicated by a leukocyte count of 15,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000).
Which one of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient’s new fever and diarrhea?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

One to six months after transplantation, patients are at elevated risk for serious illness from opportunistic infections, such as Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly P. carinii) pneumonia, fungal organisms, and gastrointestinal parasites; viral pathogens, including cytomegalovirus and other herpes group viruses and respiratory viruses (such as adenovirus); and bacterial infections, including listeriosis and mycobacterial disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Six months after transplantation, patients are at ongoing risk for opportunistic infections. Compared with the average person, they are also at increased risk for malignancies and typical community-acquired pathogens, such as norovirus.

C) CORRECT:

Infections in solid-organ transplant recipients can be categorized by the timing of infection onset. During the first month after transplantation, patients are at great risk for nosocomial infections such as Clostridioides difficile, postoperative complications such as anastomotic leaks, graft-reperfusion injuries, and donor-derived infections.

Key learning point: In the first month after solid-organ transplantation, the pathogen that is most likely to cause a new fever and diarrhea is Clostridioides difficile.

D) INCORRECT:

One to six months after transplantation, patients are at elevated risk for serious illness from opportunistic infections, such as Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly P. carinii) pneumonia, fungal organisms, and gastrointestinal parasites; viral pathogens, including cytomegalovirus and other herpes group viruses and respiratory viruses (such as adenovirus); and bacterial infections, including listeriosis and mycobacterial disease.

E) INCORRECT:

One to six months after transplantation, patients are at elevated risk for serious illness from opportunistic infections, such as Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly P. carinii) pneumonia, fungal organisms, and gastrointestinal parasites; viral pathogens, including cytomegalovirus and other herpes group viruses and respiratory viruses (such as adenovirus); and bacterial infections, including listeriosis and mycobacterial disease.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents with skin lesions on both lower extremities that appeared about 6 months ago and have been growing in size. His history is significant for human herpesvirus 8 seropositivity and two kidney allografts. The first allograft was rejected; the second was done 2 years ago. The patient reports that he had similar lesions about 4 years ago, but they healed after he stopped immunosuppressive therapy following the allograft rejection.
Physical examination reveals symmetric, bilateral, purplish-blue plaques and nodules on the lower extremities that feel spongy upon palpation. The patient denies any pain or itching.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Squamous-cell and basal-cell carcinomas account for more than 90% of all skin cancers in transplant recipients but are typically located on the hands, forearms, or upper trunk in younger patients and on the head in older patients. Basal-cell carcinoma typically appears as a pearly white, dome-shaped papule with prominent telangiectatic surface vessels.

B) CORRECT:

Patients who receive immunosuppression following organ transplantation are at risk for several skin manifestations. Kaposi sarcoma is the most common among patients who are seropositive for human herpesvirus 8 before transplantation. In post-transplant patients, the classic purplish-blue lesions of Kaposi sarcoma typically appear on the lower extremities.

Key learning point: Patients with human herpesvirus 8 seropositivity who undergo transplantation and immunosuppression have a high risk for developing Kaposi sarcoma.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

C) INCORRECT:

Squamous-cell and basal-cell carcinomas account for more than 90% of all skin cancers in transplant recipients but are typically located on the hands, forearms, or upper trunk in younger patients and on the head in older patients. Squamous-cell carcinoma most commonly appears as a firm, smooth, or hyperkeratotic papule or plaque, often with central ulceration.

D) INCORRECT:

Malignant fibrous histiocytomas of the skin are rare and may mimic the appearance of basal- or squamous-cell carcinomas. They can occur after transplantation but are typically described as erythematous, beefy, sessile solitary nodules.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster is a common viral skin infection that occurs in immunosuppressed individuals. The lesions are usually vesicular, painful, and present in distinct dermatomes.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 3-month history of worsening fatigue, loss of appetite, itching of the skin, and progressive leg swelling. She has been passing only small amounts of urine. She has type 1 diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, hypertension, and diabetic polyneuropathy. Her current medications include insulin, torsemide, lisinopril, and synthetic erythropoietin. There is 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities. Serum studies show:


Na+

137 mEq/L


K+

5.3 mEq/L


HCO3−

20 mEq/L


Urea nitrogen
85 mg/dL


Creatinine
8 mg/dL


pH
7.25


Which of the following long-term treatments would best improve quality of life and maximize survival in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Kidney transplantation is indicated for patients with ESRD. The most frequently used surgical technique is heterotopic implantation in the iliac fossa, connecting the donor ureter to the recipient bladder. Although on average cadaveric kidney transplants function for approx. 14 years, it would not be the best long-term treatment option for this 45-year-old patient, because it is not associated with the greatest survival benefit.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms of fluid overload (e.g., peripheral edema). Although fluid intake should be restricted to approximately 2 L/day in order to prevent edema in this patient, it would not be the best long-term treatment option for a patient with ESRD.

C) CORRECT:

Kidney transplantation is indicated for patients with ESRD. In these cases, it is associated with a greater long-term survival rate and a better quality of life than dialysis. The most frequently used surgical technique is heterotopic implantation of the transplant in the iliac fossa, connecting the donor ureter to the recipient bladder. Transplants received from a living donor (e.g., a family member) have a better prognosis than cadaveric kidney transplants (even in the setting of MHC mismatch). For cadaveric kidney transplant recipients, the 1-year survival rate is approx. 88%, while it is 71% at 5 years. For living donor kidney transplant recipients, the 1-year survival rate is approx. 94%, while it is 84% at 5 years. In comparison to hemodialysis, more patients with ESRD who undergo kidney transplantation regain bodily functions, including endocrine function.

Key learning point: Living donor kidney transplantation offers the best long-term improvement in quality of life and survival for patients with end-stage renal disease compared to dialysis or cadaveric transplantation.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with acidosis, electrolyte abnormalities (hyperkalemia), ingestion of toxins (increased BUN), fluid overload (edema), and uremic symptoms (itching of the skin), all of which are indications for dialysis. Although renal replacement therapy is indicated in this patient, peritoneal dialysis would not be the best long-term treatment because of a variety of potential complications that can occur (e.g., infections, metabolic disturbances) if this method is maintained incorrectly and the need for daily, time-consuming treatments.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with CKD require renal replacement therapy (RRT), and hemodialysis is the most commonly used form of RRT in the United States. Although RRT is indicated in this patient and is necessary to bridge the time to definitive treatment, hemodialysis should not be continued as a long-term treatment if another option is available, as hemodialysis is associated with a variety of potential complications (e.g., thrombosis, infection, heart failure) that may impact survival. Moreover, it must be administered at least 3 times per week, which significantly reduces quality of life. A treatment associated with a better survival rate and quality of life should be pursued if available. The 5-year survival rate of the patients on hemodialysis is approx. 30–40% overall, but is only 20% for patients with diabetic nephropathy, which is the likely etiology in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has a history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) due to diabetic nephropathy and presents with fatigue, loss of appetite, pruritus, lower extremity edema, and oliguria. In combination with the patient's hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, uremia, and increased serum creatinine, these features are consistent with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with alcohol-induced cirrhosis continues daily drinking and requests a liver transplant. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Place a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt immediately
Enforce a documented period of abstinence before listing
Pursue immediate transplant evaluation despite ongoing drinking
Begin empiric corticosteroids for presumed alcoholic hepatitis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) is indicated for portal hypertension complications like refractory variceal bleeding or ascites. The patient's issue is ongoing alcohol use, not an acute complication requiring TIPS. TIPS does not address alcohol abuse or improve transplant candidacy.

B) CORRECT:

Liver transplant guidelines for alcohol-induced cirrhosis require a documented abstinence period, often six months, before listing. This period assesses the patient's commitment to sobriety and potential liver function improvement, reducing the risk of post-transplant recidivism and complications. Abstinence is crucial for evaluating behavioral, psychosocial, and medical factors essential for transplant candidacy. Ongoing alcohol use post-transplant can negatively impact outcomes and survival, making abstinence a critical prerequisite.

Key learning point: Active alcohol use is a contraindication for liver transplantation due to the risk of poor outcomes and graft failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Most transplant centers require a documented period of abstinence to assess commitment to sobriety and reduce post-transplant recidivism risk. Active alcohol consumption increases complications, such as graft failure. The patient's ongoing alcohol use does not meet the usual sobriety requirement, making immediate evaluation inappropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are used for severe alcoholic hepatitis, characterized by acute jaundice, fever, leukocytosis, and high Maddrey Discriminant Function score. The patient has alcohol-induced cirrhosis without signs of acute inflammation, making corticosteroid therapy inappropriate and potentially harmful due to immunosuppression risks.

questions.text: You are caring for a 50-year-old man who has undergone kidney transplantation for end-stage renal disease due to long-standing polycystic kidney disease. His postoperative course has been uncomplicated. He has a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 5 years ago. He does not consume alcohol or use illicit drugs. His current medications are basiliximab, mycophenolate mofetil, and prednisone. Vital signs are normal. On examination, his surgical incisions are clean and intact. Prior to discharge, which one of the following is the most appropriate intervention for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Live vaccines, such as the varicella vaccine, are contraindicated in solid-organ transplant recipients and are usually administered at least 4 weeks before the transplantation.

B) INCORRECT:

While itraconazole would be an appropriate antifungal for prophylaxis against histoplasmosis, this is not part of the universal prophylaxis for organ transplant recipients on immunosuppressive therapy. Rather, histoplasmosis prophylaxis should be started for patients infected with HIV with CD4 counts < 150//μL who live in regions hyperendemic for histoplasmosis (e.g., Ontario, southern Quebec).

C) INCORRECT:

This patient is at risk for opportunistic viral infections such as CMV. High-dose oral acyclovir can be used for CMV prophylaxis, but it is not considered first-line and is not part of the universal prophylaxis for organ transplant recipients. Valganciclovir or ganciclovir are recommended first-line treatments for CMV prophylaxis; these agents also decrease the incidence of reactivation of other herpes virus infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Inactivated vaccines such as the meningococcal conjugate vaccine shouldn’t be restarted until maintenance immunosuppression is achieved, typically 3–6 months after solid-organ transplantation.

E) CORRECT:

Universal prophylaxis following solid organ transplantation includes Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia prophylaxis with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and CMV prophylaxis with valganciclovir or ganciclovir. This patient is on immunosuppressive therapy after kidney transplantation and should, therefore, receive both drugs. Universal prophylaxis against other opportunistic pathogens (e.g., Mycobacterium avium complex, Histoplasma) is not routinely required. As per the Canadian Immunization Guide, inactivated vaccines shouldn’t be restarted until maintenance immunosuppression is achieved, typically 3–6 months after solid-organ transplantation. Live vaccines are generally contraindicated in solid organ transplant recipients.

Key learning point: Solid organ transplantation recipients receive universal chemoprophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii and CMV.
questions.hint: Prophylaxis against the most common opportunistic pathogens, such as Pneumocystis jirovecii and human cytomegalovirus (CMV), should be administered in posttransplant patients on immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 4-day history of generalized maculopapular rash, persistent nausea, and watery diarrhea. He underwent allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation 6 weeks ago for acute leukemia and has been on cyclosporine prophylaxis. On examination, he appears mildly dehydrated with a pruritic rash and mild jaundice. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin 8.2 g/dL, platelets 45,000/μL, and alkaline phosphatase 280 U/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cyclosporine toxicity typically manifests with nephrotoxicity, hypertension, and neurotoxicity rather than the skin, gastrointestinal, and hepatic findings seen here. 

B) INCORRECT:

Although cytomegalovirus infection can cause gastrointestinal symptoms and cytopenias in immunocompromised patients, this patient's symptoms are more likely secondary to another cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Although drug-induced hypersensitivity reactions can cause rash and hepatic dysfunction, the constellation of symptoms points towards a more likely cause.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with acute graft-versus-host disease occurring after recent allogeneic stem cell transplantation. Skin involvement, gastrointestinal symptoms, and hepatic dysfunction are commonly seen in acute graft-versus-host disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Clostridium difficile colitis commonly occurs in immunocompromised patients and can cause severe diarrhea and systemic illness, but another cause is more likely.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient, who is a kidney transplant recipient, presents to the emergency department with fever, dyspnea, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates on chest x-ray. The patient received the transplant 8 months ago and is adherent to immunosuppressive therapy. Laboratory studies show normal WBC count with lymphopenia. Chest X-ray shows bilateral symmetrical interstitial infiltrates; CT chest shows ground glass opacities and pneumatoceles. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain sputum for acid-fast bacilli testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose corticosteroids worsen immunosuppression and are not indicated as initial therapy for suspected opportunistic pneumonia in transplant recipients.

B) INCORRECT:

Although antibiotic therapy is important, augmentin is not the correct agent for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

While bronchoscopy may provide a definitive diagnosis, this patient requires urgent empiric treatment to prevent clinical deterioration.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The clinical presentation of bilateral infiltrates with lymphopenia 8 months after transplantation is highly suggestive of pneumocystis pneumonia, which typically occurs within 6–12 months posttransplant. Empiric treatment with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is appropriate given the high clinical suspicion and potential for rapid deterioration.

E) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis typically occurs later than 12 months posttransplant and is less likely at 8 months without specific risk factors or focal infiltrates.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of progressively worsening pain over her left lower abdomen where she received a kidney transplant 3 months ago. She also reports decreased urine output, mild fever, and feeling generally unwell. Her blood pressure is 165/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tenderness and swelling over the transplant site. Her baseline creatinine after the transplant was 1.2 mg/dL, and today it is 3.1 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: CT angiography of the renal vessels

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's clinical presentation of graft pain, edema, fever, malaise, and elevated creatinine within 6 months of transplant strongly suggests acute transplant rejection.

B) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasound is used to evaluate for suspected vascular complications, but the combination of graft pain, swelling, fever, and progressive renal dysfunction over several days suggests an inflammatory process rather than acute vascular compromise.

C) INCORRECT:

While high-dose corticosteroids are first-line treatment for acute graft rejection, treatment decisions should be made by transplant specialists after appropriate diagnostic workup because other posttransplant complications can manifest similarly and require different approaches.

D) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is used to evaluate for vascular complications such as arterial stenosis or thrombosis, but these conditions typically have different clinical patterns and timeframes than this acute inflammatory presentation.

E) INCORRECT:

While infection should be considered in an immunocompromised patient with a transplant, the combination of graft tenderness, swelling, hypertension, and renal dysfunction in the early posttransplant period is more characteristic of rejection than infection.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at home. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated by paramedics, but he remains unresponsive on arrival. His family says he appeared healthy on the previous day. He has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. He has no history of substance use and is not married. Physical examination shows a comatose man who is intubated and mechanically ventilated. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 82/min, blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg, and respirations are controlled by the ventilator. He has fixed, dilated pupils, absent corneal and gag reflexes, and no spontaneous movements. Apnea testing confirms the absence of spontaneous respirations. The attending physician discloses the diagnosis of brain death to the family and gives some time to process the information. In a follow-up conversation, the physician addresses the topic of organ donation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Request approval from the hospital ethics committee before proceeding
Wait for a mandatory 24-hour period after brain death is declared before proceeding
Notify the local organ procurement organization for evaluation
Proceed only if the patient had a documented donor card
Obtain written consent for organ donation from the patient's mother

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the ethics committee may be involved in complex or disputed cases, its approval is not necessary for standard organ procurement procedures once brain death has been declared.

B) INCORRECT:

There is no mandatory waiting period between brain death and the initiation of the organ procurement process. Once brain death is confirmed, the patient is legally dead, and organ procurement procedures may proceed following established protocols. Prolonging the interval without a specific clinical or legal reason may reduce organ viability and is not a standard procedural step in organ donation protocols.

C) CORRECT:

Federal regulations and hospital policy require that all potential organ donors be reported to a local organ procurement organization (OPO) as soon as brain death is established or imminent, unless the deceased patient has specifically declined to become a donor (e.g., in an advance directive). The OPO is responsible for evaluating medical suitability and discussing organ donation with the family. Physicians and hospital staff should not initiate the process for donation themselves (e.g., by obtaining consent), as this may result in conflicts of interest and reduce consent rates. OPO staff are specially trained to provide support, address questions, and facilitate the process ethically and sensitively. Early notification preserves organ viability and ensures that the process respects medical, ethical, and legal standards.

D) INCORRECT:

Documented donor status is helpful but not required to initiate the process of organ donation. While a documented donor card or registration in a donor registry is legally binding in many states, organ donation evaluation should proceed even if such documentation is not available. In many cases, family members or legally authorized representatives may make decisions about donation in the absence of documented donor status, provided that other requirements and protocols are followed.

E) INCORRECT:

Written consent for organ donation may sometimes be required from the next of kin, depending on state law and the patient’s documented wishes. However, the process for obtaining and validating consent is standardized and typically involves designated professionals who are trained in these sensitive discussions.
questions.hint: There are standardized processes for donor candidates who did not explicitly decline to donate organs.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motorcycle collision. He was intubated for airway protection and is admitted to the neurointensive care unit. Past medical history is unremarkable. His driver's license identifies him as an organ donor, and his name appears on the state donor registry. On hospital day 2, two attending physicians independently complete a brain death examination; pupils are fixed and nonreactive, corneal and gag reflexes are absent, and apnea tests confirm absence of respiratory drive. He is not receiving sedatives or paralytics, and he does not have hypothermia. He remains on mechanical ventilation with stable hemodynamics. The hospital has notified the regional organ procurement organization (OPO) per policy. The patient’s father states that the family’s religious beliefs prohibit organ donation and asks the team to “stop this process.” Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain written consent from the patient's mother

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Next of kin consent for organ donation is only required if the patient's intent to donate organs is not documented or if the patient is a minor (because the consent of the legal guardian is required). This patient has given first-person authorization for organ donation, and further consent from family members is not legally necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

A court order may be necessary in the event of an unresolved legal dispute (e.g., ambiguity about the patient's identity, lack of documented donor registration). Family refusal is not a valid reason to halt organ procurement in patients who have provided first-person authorization for donation.

C) INCORRECT:

Canceling organ procurement is only appropriate if the patient's intent to donate organs is not documented, if the patient does not meet donation criteria, or if there are legal or medical contraindications to donation. In this scenario, the patient is a registered organ donor, and brain death has been confirmed. A patient's next of kin cannot override a first person authorization for organ donation.

D) CORRECT:

An individual's documented decision to become an organ donor (e.g., indicating donor status on a driver’s license) is legally binding and recognized as first person authorization. Once an individual has been declared brain-dead, assuming there are no medical (e.g., malignancy) or legal contraindications (e.g., need for legal investigation) for donation, hospitals and OPOs must respect the patient's autonomy by proceeding with organ donation. The patient's next-of-kin cannot override a valid first person authorization for any reason (e.g., religious beliefs). Clinicians should offer compassionate support and give clear information to the family but are otherwise obligated to follow the patient’s documented wishes.

Standard protocol requires notifying an OPO as soon as a patient is near death with a severe neurological injury and again within 1 hour after brain death. After notification, the OPO is responsible for evaluating the donor candidate and procuring the organ.

E) INCORRECT:

An ethics committee provides guidance in cases of moral or legal uncertainty, such as ambiguous advance directives. This patient has given first-person authorization for organ donation, and convening the ethics committee is therefore unnecessary.
questions.hint: OPOs rely on state donor registries linked to driver's license information for timely verification of patient preferences.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of confusion and anuria. He has chronic kidney disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, is HIV-positive, and has active hepatitis C infection. He was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia at the age of 8 years and was treated with an allogeneic stem cell transplantation. His current medications include tenofovir, emtricitabine, atazanavir, daclatasvir, sofosbuvir, and insulin. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Examination shows severe edema in both legs and generalized muscular weakness. Auscultation of the lungs shows crepitant rales. Laboratory studies show an undetectable HIV viral load and CD4+ T-lymphocyte count of 589/mm3. Six months ago, his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count was 618/mm3. An ECG shows arrhythmia with frequent premature ventricular contractions. The patient states he would like to donate organs or tissues in the case of his death. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for organ donation in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Absolute contraindications for organ donation include incurable or metastatic malignancy, sepsis, transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (e.g., Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease), and cardiac arrest that occurred before brain death, none of which apply to this patient. HIV infection was previously an absolute contraindication for organ donation and legally prohibited individuals from becoming organ donors in the US, but the 2015 HIV Organ Policy Equity (HOPE) act allows transplantation of organs from HIV-positive donors to HIV-positive recipients at certain institutions.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis C infection is not an absolute contraindication for organ donation. Donor organs from hepatitis C-positive donors may be offered to hepatitis C-positive recipients, even if the virus can be detected in the blood.

C) INCORRECT:

HIV infection was formerly an absolute contraindication for organ donation and legally prohibited individuals from becoming organ donors in the US. This rule was based on the principle of nonmaleficence, as transplantation of HIV-positive donor organs may pose harm to transplant recipients. However, the HIV Organ Policy Equity (HOPE) Act, implemented in November 2015, now allows transplantation of organs from HIV-positive donors to HIV-positive recipients, provided the donor has an undetectable viral load, no prior history of an opportunistic infection, no active fungal infection, and a CD4+ count over 500 cells/μL for 6 months before donation. This patient's history of HIV does not, therefore, affect his eligibility to donate his organs to HIV-positive recipients. Donor organs from HIV-positive individuals are not transplanted to non-HIV-positive patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Although incurable or metastatic malignancy is an absolute contraindication for organ donation, this patient's history of childhood leukemia with a long cancer-free interval does not prohibit organ donation. Organ donation from individuals with low-grade, localized tumors without evidence of metastasis is also permitted.
questions.hint: This patient's medical history has to be thoroughly reviewed for any incurable illnesses or malignancies.

questions.text: Twelve days after undergoing a cadaveric renal transplant for adult polycystic kidney disease, a 23-year-old man has pain in the right lower abdomen and generalized fatigue. During the past 4 days, he has had decreasing urinary output. Creatinine concentration was 2.3 mg/dL on the second postoperative day. Current medications include prednisone, cyclosporine, azathioprine, and enalapril. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 168/98 mm Hg. Examination reveals tenderness to palpation on the graft site. Creatinine concentration is 4.3 mg/dL. A biopsy of the transplanted kidney shows tubulitis. C4d staining is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

choices.text: Donor T cells from the graft
Irreversible fibrosis of the glomerular vessels
Preformed cytotoxic antibodies against class I HLA

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Calcineurin inhibitors such as cyclosporine cause reversible renal vasoconstriction, which would result in increased serum creatinine (due to a decrease in GFR caused by afferent arteriole constriction) and hypertension (due to activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system). However, the BUN:creatinine ratio would usually be > 20:1 in conditions associated with renal hypoperfusion. Also, the renal biopsy would show vacuoles within the tubular cells rather than cellular infiltrate within the tubular epithelium (tubulitis).

B) INCORRECT:

Damage to the recipient's tissue by donor T cells (graft-versus-host disease) can occur following allogenous stem cell transplantation; it is not typically seen with solid organ transplantation because most solid organ grafts (e.g., kidney, heart) do not contain much lymphoid tissue. Moreover, graft-versus-host disease typically presents with gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea), hepatic dysfunction, and skin lesions, not acute renal failure.

Allogeneic small bowel transplantation can cause graft-versus-host disease because the small bowel contains lymphoid tissue.

C) CORRECT:

Abdominal pain, hypertension, and an increase in creatinine within 6 months of renal transplantation are concerning for acute rejection of the renal allograft. There are two mechanisms for acute allograft rejection, acute cellular rejection by host T lymphocytes and acute humoral rejection by circulating antibodies. The absence of C4d staining (a marker of antibody-mediated damage) and the presence of inflammatory infiltrate within the wall of tubules (tubulitis) indicate that the most likely mechanism for graft rejection in this patient is acute cellular rejection.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of the tunica intima of glomerular vessels is a pathological finding seen in chronic renal allograft rejection, which can result in renal failure and hypertension. However, chronic rejection of the renal allograft typically presents > 6 months after the transplantation with gradually increasing creatinine and proteinuria, unlike this patient who develops acute renal failure one week after the transplantation.

E) INCORRECT:

Preformed antibodies against class I HLA of the graft is responsible for hyperacute rejection of the renal allograft, which would result in features of acute renal failure (e.g., decreased urine output, increased creatinine) as well as tubulitis on renal biopsy. However, patients with preformed antibodies would usually have a history of blood transfusion in the past or a failed organ transplantation, and the onset of acute renal failure in a case of hyperacute renal graft rejection would always occur within 48 hours of transplantation. The renal biopsy would also have shown widespread infarction, necrosis, and thrombosis as well as C4d along the glomerular and peritubular capillaries.
questions.hint: After renal transplant from a cadaveric donor, the serum creatinine should start to decrease by the end of the first week. Increasing creatinine levels within days to weeks of the renal transplantation is concerning for acute rejection of the renal allograft.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Three months ago, she underwent heart transplantation for restrictive cardiomyopathy and was started on transplant rejection prophylaxis. Her pulse is 76/min and blood pressure is 148/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows enlargement of the gum tissue. There is a well-healed scar on her chest. Serum studies show hyperlipidemia. The physician recommends removing a drug that decreases T cell activation by inhibiting the transcription of interleukin-2 from the patient's treatment regimen and replacing it with a different medication. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause of the adverse effects seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sirolimus is an immunosuppressant drug that can be used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. It binds FK binding protein (FKBP) to form a complex that inhibits mTOR. This inhibition prevents activation of mTOR kinase, which leads to inhibition of interleukin-2 (IL-2) induced T cell proliferation and impaired B cell differentiation. Sirolimus does not inhibit the transcription of IL-2. Side effects of this drug include hypertension and hyperlipidemia, as seen in this patient. However, it is not known to cause gingival hyperplasia. Further important adverse effects of sirolimus include infection, malignancy, pancytopenia, and insulin resistance.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone are commonly used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. They exert their immunosuppressant effect via various mechanisms of action, including inhibition of NF-κB, suppression of T cell proliferation, and induction of apoptosis in lymphocytes. Glucocorticoids have a wide range of side effects including hypertension and hyperlipidemia, as seen in this patient. However, this group of drugs is not known to cause gingival hyperplasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Tacrolimus is an immunosuppressant drug that is commonly used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. It binds FK binding protein (FKBP) to form a complex that inhibits calcineurin. Inhibition of calcineurin blocks activation of the NFAT transcription factors, which prevents interleukin-2 transcription and, as a result, decreases T cell activation. Side effects of this drug include hypertension and hyperlipidemia, as seen in this patient. However, it is not known to cause gingival hyperplasia. Further important adverse effects instead include infection, malignancy, new-onset diabetes mellitus, nephrotoxicity, and neurotoxicity. Although the mechanism of action of tacrolimus is consistent with the drug that the physician recommended to remove from this patient's treatment regimen, the reported adverse effects are more likely caused by a different medication.

D) CORRECT:

Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant drug that is commonly used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. It binds cyclophilin to form a complex that inhibits calcineurin. Inhibition of calcineurin blocks activation of the NFAT transcription factors, which prevents interleukin-2 transcription and, as a result, decreases T cell activation. Cyclosporine is the only calcineurin inhibitor to cause gingival hyperplasia, so it is most likely the drug that was used in this patient.

Further important side effects of cyclosporine include increased susceptibility to infection and increased risk for malignancy.
Image Description:

Mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) acts by inhibiting inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH), resulting in selective inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation.

Azathioprine (AZA) is a purine analog that is converted, first, to 6-mercaptopurine and, then, into thioinosine monophosphate (TIM), a cytotoxic agent, which acts to block nucleotide synthesis and inhibit lymphocyte proliferation.

Methotrexate (MTX) is a folic acid antagonist (antimetabolite), which acts primarily by inhibiting the clonal expansion of B and T cells.

Cyclophosphamide causes alkylation of DNA/RNA, resulting in impaired DNA cross-linking and DNA synthesis.

Basiliximab/daclizumab inhibits the alpha chain (CD25 antigen) of the IL-2 receptor of T cells, resulting in a reduction of T-cell responses and the expansion of natural killer cells.

Sirolimus/everolimus inhibits mTOR kinase resulting in the inhibition of the IL-2-mediated cell cycle. This leads to reduced T-cell activation and B-cell differentiation, resulting in decreased IgM, IgG, and IgA production.

Tacrolimus (FK 506) and pimecrolimus bind to the FK506 binding protein (FKBP) resulting in inhibition of calcineurin, an enzyme necessary for the activation of NFAT. This leads to reduced gene transcription and activation of T cells. Cyclosporine A binds cyclophilin, which also inhibits calcineurin.

Glucocorticoids (corticosteroids) directly inhibit intracellular NF-κB, a protein complex responsible for transcription of DNA, cytokine production, and cell survival.

E) INCORRECT:

Azathioprine is an immunosuppressant drug that can be used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. Azathioprine is a precursor of 6-mercaptopurine, an antimetabolite that blocks purine synthesis and subsequently inhibits the proliferation of lymphocytes. It does not inhibit the transcription of interleukin-2. Important adverse effects of azathioprine include bone marrow suppression (leading to pancytopenia), hepatotoxicity, acute pancreatitis, infection, malignancy, and fetal harm in pregnant women. Azathioprine is not known to cause any of the adverse effects observed in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Mycophenolate mofetil is an immunosuppressant drug that is commonly used for transplant rejection prophylaxis. It inhibits inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase, which impairs lymphocyte purine synthesis and subsequently inhibits lymphocyte proliferation. Mycophenolate mofetil does not inhibit the transcription of interleukin-2. Side effects of this drug include hypertension and hyperlipidemia, as seen in this patient. However, it is not known to cause gingival hyperplasia. Further important adverse effects of mycophenolate mofetil include first-trimester pregnancy loss and congenital malformations, infection, malignancy, neutropenia, and hyperglycemia.
questions.hint: In addition to the hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and gingival hyperplasia seen in this patient, other adverse effects of this medication include hirsutism, nephrotoxicity, and neurotoxicity.
